Offspring of Pride and lawless Pow'r,</br>Whom Folly, in an evil hour,</br>The gifts of Fortune to defeat,</br>Brought forth, the torment of the Great!</br>Caprice!  go vent thy little rage</br>On vice, deformity, or age:</br>There tyrannize with boundless sway,</br>Nor youth and beauty make thy prey.

With those bright eyes, that blooming face,</br>That shape, and air, and winning grace;</br>With all that wit and taste impart,</br>To hold in captive chains the heart:</br>Yet, Laura, with what fatal haste</br>Your fleeting moments run to waste!</br>Your spring of life, alas!  is o'er,</br>That joyous age that comes no more!</br>You captives make, yet not a swain</br>But soon, disgusted, breaks his chain.</br>Caprice those brilliant eyes disarms,</br>An antidote to all your charms!</br>Fraught with the power to save or kill,</br>You lovers gain to treat them ill;</br>To-day you smile, to-morrow frown:</br>You raise our hopes, then spurn them down;</br>Now spread and now contract your sail,</br>As fancy and caprice prevail.</br>Would any wretch embark for life</br>With such a fair — fantastic wife?

No; rather let me stem the tide,</br>Without a helm my bark to guide;</br>The sport of waves and varying winds,</br>Than trust to such capricious minds,</br>Where whim and passion hold the rein,</br>And slighted reason pleads in vain.

Tho' Fortune on our prospects smiles,</br>Caprice our fairest hopes beguiles.</br>Tho' blest with friends, with youth and health,</br>And all the gay parade of wealth;</br>With equipage, a mansion fair,</br>With turrets glittering high in air;</br>Our lawns extend, our waving woods</br>Inverted nod from silver floods;</br>With every earthly means of bliss,</br>Our roads to happiness we miss.</br>Capricious Fancy's dazzling light</br>Misleads us, like a dancing spright:</br>Thro' woods and wilds we vagrant roam,</br>And never reach our destin'd home.

Nature decks out a various feast,</br>To humour each fastidious guest;</br>But Fancy, like a wayward child,</br>By too indulgent parents spoil'd,</br>Indignant kens the offer'd treat:</br>Tho' urged by hunger, scorns to eat;</br>Turns from mamma with angry eye;</br>And frets and pouts — it knows not why.</br>
